translated: Elder’s Birth Stories
The Chapter with Threes
The Elder Āmaṇḍaphaladāyaka’s Birth Story
“The Victor named Padumuttara,
who had gone beyond all things,
arose from his concentration
and the world’s guide was pacing up and down.
I was carrying a load of sugar cane
and I was bringing some fruit.
I saw the Buddha, free from defilements,
the great sage pacing up and down.

analyzed: pasanna cittaḥ sumanaḥ  sire katvāna añjali
translated: With a confident and joyful mind,🔽I put my palms together above my head
and I paid homage to the Sambuddha
and I gave him a mango fruit.

analyzed: sata sahassitaḥ kappe  yam phalam adadim tadā
translated: For a hundred thousand eons
I did not go to a bad rebirth🔽because of that fruit I gave then:
this is the fruit of the mango.
My defilements were burned up,
I live without defilements.
How welcome it was for me
I have done what had to be done for the Buddha’s teaching.
The four analytical insights,
I have done what had to be done for the Buddha’s teaching.”🔽Thus the elder Āmaṇḍaphaladāyaka recited these verses.

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā āmaṇḍaphaladāyako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.🔽Āmaṇḍaphaladāyakattherassāpadānaṁ navamaṁ.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmai āmaṇḍaphaladāyakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati 🔽āmaṇḍaphaladāyaka therassa apadānam navama
translated: The Elder Āmaṇḍaphaladāyaka’s Birth Story, the ninth.
